The instructor does not seem to care that many of his students are not going to be epidemiologists. The prime example is the required memorization of 20+ obscure formulas I will never use later in my career. The lectures are just reading off a slide- I found that 70% of the class didn't even bother attending.

Having multiple choice tests with no room for partial credit is lazy grading and does not measure how well we have learned the material. This shows very well in the class average on tests (78%, in an intro course).

The course material was great, and it gave me a wonderful foundation for epidemiology. My one problem was that the lectures were often very dry, and classes consisted of Dr. Risch reading directly off the powerpoints, so it was difficult to remain engaged. I also feel like some important concepts that would be critical for homework/exams were reviewed a bit haphazardly during lecture; much of my time preparing for assignments and exams was me trying to teach myself things that should have been more emphasized in class.
This course is well-taught and provides a broad overview of the basic concepts in epidemiology.

Very interesting concepts. can be improved by making homework shorter and spending more time learning concepts and doing practice problems. Also i do not see the point of not bringing in formulas to exam. I would rather be tested on how to apply these rather than simply memorizing it.
strengths include Dr. Risch being a generally nice person, just not a great instructor. Concepts in lectures were not explained beyond what was included in the slides.

Strengths:  weekly discussion sections with problem sets

Weaknesses:  complicated lectures slides with an overwhelming amount of non-pertinent information

Very interesting material. I found that I could apply what I learned in this class in other classes as well as in my research involvement. The problem sets and structure of 3 exams were good since they helped with material retention. 

However, the exams were poorly written for the most part. The wording of many questions was awkward and ambiguous, and it was concerning how this trend was common among all three hourly exams. The lectures were not engaging, since it involved reading off a powerpoint presentation. I noticed many people stopped showing up for this reason.

I occasionally felt frustrated by the inappropriate depth of the content that was covered in an "introductory" course. I sometimes felt that the instructor inserted too much of his own opinion on certain topics, and this complicated the subject and detracted from my understanding of the material. I sometimes felt as though the exams were made up of purposefully tricky questions (unfriendly or unclear language that the TFs could not or would not clarify) and very specific examples discussed maybe only once in a single lecture.
Terribly taught course. Students were unengaged and professor did not meet the needs of his students. Tested on material not covered in class. Only redeeming factor was the group of supporting TAs.
good introduction to epidemiology, lectures could be more engaging
The material was a bit hard to follow (semi unorganized and seemed repetitive at times), but there was a lot covered in a short amount of time which was impressive.

Strength: a good introductory course. I could learn a lot. Lecture notes are well organized and self explanatory. 

Weakness: There are three midterms, which make the workload a bit heavy.
The course itself is a decent intro to epidemiology

This course was my biggest disappointment so far at Yale. Our professor did a horrible job conveying topics in lecture and I found myself relying almost entirely on self-study and section. As an HCM student with limited science background, this course was a challenge, but one I looked forward to. Since my science knowledge isn't as robust, this will likely be the only Epi course I take. Unfortunately, I am leaving it feeling bad about my performance and what I took away from the course. I found that all the learning I did was entirely based on trying to answer homework assignments or test prep, and no natural learning took place.
Exam questions did not reflect homework assignments and practice problems

I feel the material was very important to learn and was all new to me. However, I feel the material was poorly presented in lecture. Lectures were not engaging and slides tended to be too wordy. This made it hard to take notes in class by hand as I could not keep up.

The exams are unnecessarily difficult and the questions are ambiguous at times. Rather than focusing on challenging students with ambiguously worded questions, questions should be made more so that they reflect true understanding on the materials. Also, it is not really fair for students to be able to know answers that weren't taught in lectures.
not a good way to teach a fundamental topic of public health but discussion section was so great

Strengths- professor is extremely bright and the course spans a wide range of material
Weaknesses- lectures were read from slides, professor was not accustomed to teaching intro level material
boring and repetitive contents plus assignments
way too much information that was not presented in a learnable way

The coursework did not align with the test.  For example, the powerpoints were different than the homework, which were different than the practice problems, which were different than the tests.  Additionally, there weren't enough practice problems to feel prepared for problem based-exams.  

But, looking back I feel like I learned a lot.  I just feel like I taught myself a lot of it.

This was hands down the worst class of the year.  I stopped attending lecture after the first few weeks because there was no point to going.  I had to teach myself 100% of the material because the lecture and the lecture slides were overwhelmingly confusing and completely unhelpful.  I am offended that after all the money I pay to attend this school, this was the quality of class I got in return.  As someone who is in the EMD department, I am gravely concerned that my foundation of epidemiology is too poor to even try to build on.  I worry for my future education and career because of how little I learned in this class.
a lot of contents

Overall, the material was good and is important to know if you want to enter the public health community. However, the instructor was not the best. While his powerpoint slides were pretty good, he didn't provide any additional information that wasn't on the slide, so class was pretty boring. He was also very snarky about particular topics, and on exams he was really bad at phrasing his questions. I could never tell whether he was asking a trick question or whether he just poorly phrased the question.

Strengths: This class made students push themselves. It moved quickly with a lot of difficult topics to cover. It did a nice job of covering the basics of Epi and laying out the framework for future classes.
Weaknesses: The homework was difficult to complete, and I feel as though the lecture notes did not adequately prepare us to do the homework. One homework would take hours to complete.
Improvement: Make class notes more tailored to completing the homework.
The lecture was dry, Harvey was not engaging, and it was honestly my least favorite class

It gives me a general introduction to epidemiology, which is very useful for my future research. Discussion session indeed helped me to understand the material thoroughly.

What I always felt in this course is that statistics in epidemiology should be more emphasized.

the strengths of the course is that there is a lot of knowledge to be gained and learned from the lectures and the material is very pertinent to public health application and research. 

the weakness of the course is that it is extremely conceptual with little engagement with the professor. a majority of the class is lecture based and no discussion which doesn't really enhance learning.

I know many students would complain about this class, but I really loved it! Prof Risch usually used very complex syntax to explain concepts, and as an international, I would find it harder to follow sometimes, but fortunately, we have the records, and I could come back to where I didn't really understand, and it was very helpful during the final weekActually, I believe if I am more familiar with English language, I would be enjoy much more than I could've in this class - whenever I went back to the video, lectures were really well-structured and logical. The way Prof. Risch spoke and structured the class was truly amazing. Especially enjoyed all those cartoons throughout the whole courses!!

Overall, a challenging course but very useful in its practical applications. 
Discussion sections are helpful.

The class needed more exciting examples; a lot of the examples used were outdated or overdone. In an evolving field like public health, there were various diseases and case studies that could have been discussed in order to make the subject more applicable.
Content could have been interesting but was presented very poorly; more examples of real-life application would have been better
I learned a lot from this course.
Lectures were not engaging and presentation slides had way too much text. However, the TFs were very helpful in understanding and clarifying the material.

Principles of epi is fundamental for the public health research. The strength of this class included the details of scientific knowledge on epidemiology, systematic methods of conducting epi investigations and analytical skills. I liked the online course format since it made the time of joining in the class much more flexible. Also the online course format made it possible to review the lecture for some difficulties several times. However, the weakness is that the speed of professor is a little bit fast on class, sometimes I cannot catch him, also, I think the professor need to translate some difficulties into understandable language instead of just reading the slides, which will make students truly understand it.

The large class size of this course was its main detriment in my opinion. It was hard to be engaged in this heavily didactic environment. I would have prepared to learn the material in a more intimate, discussion-based setting. Discussion sections were effecting in providing this environment, and this is where I learned the most I believe, and was were I could bolster my understanding. The content was dense and heavily detail oriented but also was effective at pointing out important concepts nested within the material.

I think that there is great room for improvement in the development of this course. Lecture was not very engaging and I really felt like I could prepare myself for exams by just reading the lecture slides. The slides themselves had so much written information on them, it was almost difficult to sort through to understand what was most valuable.

I wish the instructor didn't just read off the powerpoints. I stopped going to class halfway through the semester because I could get the exact same information looking off the powerpoints at home. Why am I paying for an instructor to teach when it doesn't seem like his presence makes any difference?

One strength of this course was the sections with TAs on Fridays. I think it was a good way to connect what we were learning throughout the week with specific examples. I also enjoyed that the homework was pass/fail because it took the pressure off of getting every answer right and allowed me to focus on learning in general. 

One weakness of this course was the lectures. I know that I could have learned more from a smaller class size and more face time with the professor and other students. 

I am also very annoyed that I bought a book for the course, and the course barely followed it. 

I am also annoyed that we had to memorize equations for the tests. Memorization is an outdated, ineffective, and inefficient teaching model and its actually kind of embarrassing that Yale is still allowing professors to enforce that especially in a field as applied as Public Health. The time spent memorizing those equations that I have since forgotten could have been used to read, expand my skillset, or expand my knowledge in general.
The course was well organized and easy to follow. And topics were important and fundamental. However, I feel four exams were too intensive.

The instruction itself was not very engaging, however, given that it is an intro course it is understandable. The information is very thorough, and although confusing at parts, I learned a lot. The TF's were great and really helped us retain the information. The weekly homeworks were also helpful in retaining the information. I thought the tests were a little too difficult to be warranted- confusing wording on multiple choice problems.
The lectures were not helpful in this course. The TF's were amazing.

I did not enjoy this course. My primary complaint was that I felt as if I was teaching myself the material. The material presented in lecture was not well explained, it was simply provided making it so students had to teach themselves to understand and implement all of the material. Additionally, the evaluations (ie tests) were very complicated (far more than necessary), with confusing wording. Even if one felt like the mastered the material and concepts and could explain it to others and understand what was going on, the wording of the tests made it so it was not a completely fair representation of how much students knew. I think this is an important topic and course, however I think there is room to make it enjoyable and connect better to students interests.
this course was not taught well. The professor did not explain concepts well and was not good at keeping students interested in the course material.

The course is set up with good pace and progression. The recordings were also very helpful. 

However, I found that there was often a lack of transparency to the grading scheme and at times this was frustrating. It never became clear if tutorial was mandatory to attend, and after asking the TAs they often said that it was. However, there is no mention of attendance on the grading scheme. When told a student would miss class, they would express disapproval. 

Further, students were told that if they did not attend and did not get the homework 100% correct they would fail that homework. However, this was not enforced and was not equitable for the people who attended class, believing it was mandatory.

Dr. Risch is friendly and (obviously) very knowledgable. However, I was disappointed in his teaching technique. He largely just read off of the slides, which made the class quite boring when it could have been engaging. Additionally, many of the questions on the homework and on the exams were worded in odd ways that made it very difficult to convey that we have in fact learned in the class. 

Although I think this class definitely could have been improved in a myriad of ways, I think many of the judgments my peers pass on are unfair. Yes, it was frustrating to have the slides read off for is in class (however, Dr. Risch made it an option to just not come to class). On the other hand, I think many students just chose to not try in the class/engage in the material. 

In my opinion, Dr. Risch presented all of the information that was necessary to learn for Epidemiology I. I will admit that at times discussion section had to be utilized more as a time to learn the material than to review it, as it was not presented in an fully accessible way in class. I understand how this is very frustrating/unfair for some. 

Ultimately, I think Dr. Risch had interesting insight into the field of epidemiology (especially the problems at hand for publishing research). If Dr. Risch is to teach the class in the future changes would definitely need to be made, however, he is more than competent in the material to continue to teach.

I felt like I had to put in an enormous amount of extra effort to learn the concepts that were presented in this course to make up for a lack of understanding in class.  I feel like I got lucky to have a Teaching Fellow who was an excellent teacher and helped explain the concepts in an easy-to-understand way.  The Friday discussion sections should definitely be retained in the future.
The class helped me learn and understand the basics of public health overall - what research in the field looks like.
I, along with many other students, essentially taught ourselves the material.  Going to lecture was not helpful in any way.

Content is great and informative, but the way the instructor present is not engaging at all, resulting in more students listening to the video recording at home. Too many exams throughout one semester, which made the courses workload pretty intense. In terms of the content, some more cases incorporated into the theoretical stuff can be helpful.
Good class. Covered wide range of topics and the slides were very thorough, informative and helpful.

This was a very poor course.  Unfortunately, we would receive lecture slides, and Dr. Risch strictly read off the slides.  He did not provide any real examples or context.  I am somebody who benefits from seeing example problems done out while I learn, especially when it comes to math and equations.  In this course, there was a pre-typed example on the lecture slides that we would not go over (except for it being read to us).  It can be difficult to teach yourself new mathematical concepts.

The course was much larger than expected and delivered as a lecture in the auditorium. There was minimal discussion, and the professor read the slides word for word so you did not really have to attend lecture. I found it more helpful to read the textbook and look over my TA's slides. Discussion was much more helpful than lecture, and it would have been nice to have either a longer discussion to review course material, or smaller lectures, or only online lectures and in person discussions.

Strengths:
-achieves primary objective of teaching basic epidemiological principles and concepts
-homework helped to review that weeks topics
-discussion allowed expanded inquiry into the subject material, as well as some clarification 

Weaknesses:
- lectures felt unnecessary most of the time
-there was so disjointment in what to expect for exams and how material would be tested, which may be due to the change in primary intstructer from previous years
-I felt some exam questions were too vague 
- Homework/ assignments were often difficult to handle and took a long time to finish

It is a good starting place to be used for future courses in epidemiology. All the basic concepts are covered very smartly.

The instructor follows the recommended book very closely which is again a good thing to follow up on the lecture materials and to prepare for the tests.

The video lectures were the most positive aspect of this course. It is unfortunate that this class was taught in such a boring and monotone manner, especially at a place like Yale--YSPH, please do better when selecting professors for courses that students are required to take. With the time commitment that the homework assignments required, this portion of the course should have been raised to at least 30%. The exams were exercises in absolute subjectivity and frustration, with many fellow first-years agreeing that some of the questions in no way tested actual understanding of the material but rather obscure or random interpretations. Hoping that the mediocrity of required courses does not continue....
Class needs to be curved especially since the professor was so poor

I attended all of the lectures for the first exam before realizing how unhelpful they were. For the rest of the semester, I taught myself the material to finish the homework assignments before discussion section. I found that it was much easier to teach myself the material than actually attend lecture.
learned a lot! discussion sessions were helpful!

Overall, I think the material covered in the course is excellent and helps build a strong foundation for future coursework or employment in the field of epidemiology.  I also find that Professor Harvey is extremely supportive of students needs and very willing to meet with students to review the material.  I also found most of the TAs to be very helpful and willing to take time out of their schedules to support students' studying habits (special shout out to Sneha Kannoth and Naimisha Movva).  My one major critique is that the presentation of the material in lecture can be dry since the professor is reading the powerpoint out loud word for word.  As a result, most students found it more convenient to watch the video captured lectures on their own time.  Perhaps a better alternative would be to present the material in a more engaging way where students are asked to answer questions or partake in other "hands on" activities.
Do not take with Professor Risch - was horrible.
It is a very helpful course to let you know the basic concepts of epidemiology.

The content is useful.

The instructor just read the ppt
The course was very informative but could have been more engaging
This course is excellent for epidemiology students.
A very good introduction course for epidemiology. We are taught with the fundamental knowledge to understand public health issues and research in this field.
It was an okay course. While complicated, the material was interesting
Useful, but heavily relied on the TA's to understand material.

The course would be significantly better if it were not taught as a 150-person lecture. Learning epidemiology through powerpoint slides is not a useful way of learning. I did not feel engaged with the course at all. 

The weekly homework assignments were not useful in learning material and poorly prepared me for the exams. The exams also poorly reflected material covered in class. Despite numerous reassurances otherwise, questions seemed designed to "trick" students. This made the course not feel at all like an introductory epidemiology course.

In addition, there was enormous variability between section TFs. Some were extremely helpful, while others were very unhelpful. This should be standardized.

In all, I felt like I have ended this semester with an extremely weak grasp of epidemiology, which is unacceptable for an MPH program.

Lectures often left me feeling confused about material. I relied heavily on section for instruction and clarification. The textbook readings were dense, in my opinion, and homework assignments would have benefited from additional, supplementary readings.

I was disappointed in this course because I think epi is a really interesting subject and I wish my introduction to it had been different. Dr. Risch never did anything but read directly off the slides, never said anything that wasn't written down, and so it became clear early on that it wasn't necessary to attend lecture or even listen to the recorded version later, since you could just read the slides yourself. Because of this, I felt like I was just teaching myself epi from some online slides, which is frustrating when you're spending an obscene amount of money to be here. The discussion sections were better, because we actually talked about the homework and got to apply it, but even then there was some confusion and it was clear that even the TAs were a little skeptical of how Dr. Risch was approaching the course. The slides from the TAs were exponentially more helpful than Dr. Risch's. Our practice problems for the exam weren't in the same format as the exams at all, so they weren't helpful in terms of timing or any true or false questions, etc. Overall I feel like I did learn a lot, but I probably could have learned about the same amount if I had just bought the book for fun and read it.
The discussion sections were great and super helpful.

- exams poorly designed, unclear wording
- lectures were confusing and ineffective
- learned majority of material from online resources
It was helpful that the instructor connected struggling students to a tutor after the second exam. In general, there wasn't much motivation to attend lecture.
Great content
Great course
It is the core course of MPH and very helpful.
It is a useful class

I liked the yellow boxes
The PowerPoint slides were good, but sometimes confusing and seemingly contradictiry.
The course is very great to help you master the basic knowledge of the epidemiology.

I'd been looking forward to this course, as it is my first exposure to epidemiology (didn't major in public health during undergrad, etc) - I realize that it was difficult to account for faculty absences, but I was still disappointed by the quality of the course even despite this fact. Looking back on the semester, I wish that the instructor had taken steps to actively engage students during lecture, instead of reading off the slides nearly verbatim.

Strengths: interesting introduction 

Weakness: No opportunity to utilize what we learned in class through research project

Exams emphasized memorizing sometimes

i think that the first unit of the class should've been examining study types, and then later moving into the measures of association. as a student who hasn't taken math since high school, moving into math so quickly was very challenging. i also believe that the practice test, especially for the first exam, needed to be more indicative of the exam.
Has foundational epi knowledge, but seems like it does not delve too deeply into the content.

Even if I did not always do the best on exams, I felt likt they were well designed and tested our understanding of the material fairly well. However, I thought some multiple choice questions were unnecessarily tricky. 

I really like the actual set-up of the course with our discussion sections on Friday.

Strength of the course was the discussion sessions and the way hw  was evaluated  

Weakness was the instructor and that there wasnt much of a benefit to go to class since it was all exactly read from the ppt

The lecture is very large and does not encourage student participation. The TF system is good for allowing students some interaction with instructors and peers and gives the opportunity to ask questions.
It is great. I think the media course helps me a lot.

Look, frankly, epidemiology is a subject that I find interesting until I have to start doing it. This is the second "EPI 101" course I've taken, and I just can't get engaged for the life of me. Essentially, I was never really engaged but that isn't inherently the course's fault (although it would've been nice for it to spark some heretofore dead fire). That said, I did like the course structure (focused around TA sessions) and would actually advocate for retaining the book at the start. Also, lecture was fairly redundant.
It very useful when we continue into our professional field in public health.

Overall this course was very disappointing. This is supposed to be a foundational course for any student of public health and sadly this did not provide me with the foundation I need to understand epidemiology. Strengths would be the course design: we learned a great deal from the homework assignments and meeting with TA's on Friday for discussion. I think also splitting up the course material exams into 4 was a great idea since it is a lot of a material to cover. Weaknesses: the course instructor. He would merely read from powerpoint slides for 30 minutes on average for each class. Was not great about slowing down or further explaining concepts to students. Was not great at answering questions in a way that students would understand anything better. The exams often used very nuanced language that I feel did not test me on my knowledge of epidemiology, but instead was complex sentences that were unclear, so I wouldn't know how to best answer the question at hand. The homework assignments were designed much better. Students understood what was being asked of them much better in homework assignments and during discussion. It is unfortunate this couldn't translate better to the exams.
Course provides fundamental knowledge of epidemiology, which is an essential component of public health

The course would have been a great introduction to epidemiology if not for Prof. Risch's poor teaching. The concepts and test questions were only confusing because he did not explain them properly. I relied on the weekly TA sections to understand what was going on, and I would not have had a grasp of the material if not for my TA.

This course provides an overview of essential knowledge for epidemiology. It was really challenging for someone who has never studied this before and I needed to meet with teaching fellows each week to understand material. Although I was able to raise my hand in the lecture, it was not as engaging as I wished it would be.

Strengths 
- The textbook is comprehensive and easy to follow.
- The subject material is fascinating and the lecture slides are detailed. 

Weaknesses 
- Dr. Risch delivers lectures in a monotone voice and is not engaging despite clearly being passionate about epidemiology. 
- All of the exams are poorly worded so that students do not even know what is being asked. The exams would benefit greatly from being read over by the TAs before being administered.

I really liked having TF sessions each week where we reviewed the material and went over the homework. It was also nice that homework was 20% of our grade and we graded on effort instead of accuracy. This took a lot of pressure off. However, I think the exams were not representative of our understanding of the material. The questions were vague and poorly written. I also think the Powerpoint slides for the class were terrible: too much information on each slide. A lot of extraneous information was on there and it made the salient material hard to digest.
I think Harvey is a very sweet man and means well but the course was not very organized and the slides made simple concepts very confusing
Topics are intriguing

This course was absolutely, hands-down THE WORST course I have ever taken in my life. It was truly a disappointment, and I expected more from Yale (this course, at times, made me question my decision to come here - especially as it is such a foundational course in public health). Weaknesses included that: the instructor showed up to class and only read off of the PowerPoints (word-for-word, verbatim, quickly - we only ever ended class on time twice, otherwise we were out like thirty-minutes early every day); limited practice materials that mirrored what we were expected to know for exams; minimal overview of practice problems or useful examples in class; professor neglected to answer many questions in class and seemed annoyed having to do so ("we'll go over that in a later slide"); expectations not clearly articulated; etc.

Not sure whether it was the course or instructor but learning seemed to be on the back burner at times, especially with tests. It seemed more about tricky questioning and vague wording than learning and understanding material.

overall the course was excellent. The strengths of it were the TA session for homework and review. There were media sources online so that I could review the class again and again. The weakness was that the harkness auditorium was a bad place for the class because the light is so dim.

The course was well-organized with fantastic TF's.  The lectures are all posted online, which was great because then you can just watch the classes on 1.5x or 2x speed.  The textbook assigned for the class was helpful- the lectures were basically the textbook chapters in spoken form.  Nothing too advanced or crazy in this course- all very basic material.
The lectures were very dry and delivered too slowly. I'm not sure how to improve on this.
The topics in the class were interesting, but lectures were often confusing.  I felt as though the topics could have been taught in a different way so that we could better grasp the concepts.

This course does a good job of preparing students for work in the field of epidemiology. The test questions are theoretical in nature and students would be best suited to read and think about the material rather than just do lots of practice problems.

STRENGTHS
-- The PowerPoints were well-organized, succinct, and amusing.
-- The homework assignments were generally very relevant to the exams.
WEAKNESSES
-- Some of the homework and exam questions felt more like riddles than questions, requiring puzzling through unnecessarily complex wording rather than answering a substantial question. Im grateful to the TAs for reviewing the questions in advance, or it might have been more of a rabbit hole for me.

IT IS VERY USEFUL.
AND I THINK THE FORMAT OF SEVERAL SMALL EXAMS THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER HELPS ME UNDERSTAND THE CONTENTS BETTER AND I LOVE IT.
I thought the course was a good introduction to epidemiology. My TF, Naimisha, was really helpful.

The course content was something I was looking forward to given my non-science background and the importance of epidemiology to Public Health. However, I felt the course could have been executed better. The lectures did not seem to translate well into the way the material was tested.
The class covered all the basics of epidemiology, but the content was not presented in an engaging or interactive way.

This course was very informative and covered a lot of material and basic epidemiology concepts, however the instruction was somewhat overwhelming and unclear at times. Homework didn't always match the exams, and there was a lot of unnecessary confusion in both wording and key concepts for many exam questions. Overall I feel I learned a lot, but it took a lot of work outside the classroom to fully understand the lectures.

The biggest weakness of the course was the integration of problem sets into the larger course work. Having a mandatory Friday morning section is a big time commitment both for students and TFs, and I think they were a missed opportunity to better incorporate homework into the class. 

The 20 percent, pass/fail set up of the homework basically resulted in people doing very minimal preparation (I also noticed several students actually completing the homework in class as we went over the work, which I didn't think was fair or helpful). I would propose: 1)making problem sets 40 percent of the grade 2) having problem sets due at Thursday midnight before the section 3) using the nearly 90 minute sections to have more interactive group work, including incorporating group problem solving into the section. I think these changes could better utilize the time set aside for section, encourage meaningful engagement with practice problems, and incentivize fairness. 

I also think it would be great to have 2 practice questions incorporated into every lecture, to encourage practice/engagement with material, and to help break up lecture a little bit.

It could be improved by:
1. More engaging lectures
2. Better primary readings and articles
3. Clearer homework and exam questions

The weekly homework were helpful to understand the course materials, and as a guide for the exams. The instructor made the class organized and informative. The class slides can be difficult to understand sometimes, but the textbook served as a supplemental study tool for the class. The TF office hours was definitely a bonus to the class.

It would have been helpful to have had practice problems outside of the weekly homeworks that we could have worked through in class. The exams were written in a different style than the homeworks so I would have benefited from additional practice.
it is a good class for students to understand the basic concepts of epidemiology.
PPT should be clearer
the exams were often different than the practice exams which made it difficult

strength: learned much about epidemiology.


weakness: to much homework
The discussion groups were the best format to learn and engage with the material.

Strengths - This course had weekly homework assignments that kept us on top of what we were learning and help us accountable to keeping up with the material, so I never felt like I had to "cram" for exams.  
Weaknesses - Lectures were somehow unhelpful, as the professor just read off the slides and did not walk us through how to actually calculate and use the epidemiological formulas and concepts.  Therefore, this made studying for exams extremely difficult.  I felt like we were not given much guidance on how to succeed on exams.  It is also extremely unfair that I got points taken off on the exam for material that was written incorrectly on a TF's slide.  Overall, I felt very frustrated with this course and although I had taken a prior epidemiology course and spent over 15+ hours studying for exams, I definitely struggled with doing well on the exams.
It is very straight forward to what you need to know and what is important.  I do not think memorising formulas is the best use of our time, but it does help reinforce people knowing them.

Actually attending lecture was completely useless to most students as all of the information was in the powerpoint uploaded following lecture. In terms of content, the class gave a good overview of epidemiological concepts and the discussion section was pertinent to deeper grasp of the material.
The weekly homeworks were helpful. The newly integrated recorded video of the lecture was also helpful in reviewing the materials as it's a info-heavy class.

The course material was very helpful in understanding the foundations of epidemiology. Our TAs were wonderful and homework assignments were helpful. However, more resources would be helpful to study for exams. Also, the instructor was a bit dry in his style of teaching.

This is a good introduction to epidemiology for those who have never taken a similar course in the past.  You learn a lot of frameworks to help you build your understanding of epidemiology.  It would be helpful if the examples given in class were elaborated on more thoroughly so students can see the impact epidemiologic work plays out in the real world.
Good course, buttdifficult to prepare for the exams given the short turnaround time between reviewing exam practice problems and the exam date (less than 48 hours).
Good broad knowledge. Lot of busy work.

I learned the material least effectively from lectures, perhaps just because the lecture was so large. Having access to the recorded lectures was very helpful for this course. However, I do not believe that memorizing equations for the exam was helpful or productive. I cannot think of a situation in the real world in which we will not have access to the epidemiological formulas necessary to preform analysis. The time spent time memorizing the equations required for the exams would have been better allocated covering further relevant material.
The material is helpful but too much to study in a single course.

Given the reviews of previous instructors who taught Intro to Epi, I was very disappointed with the new professor. Everything was read verbatim from a slide so students stopped attending lectures. The only feedback we got was from TA's who had taken the class last year. He did not leave any room for questions or clarification in a lecture. Seems like he was just phoning it in because he was required as part of his job.

I will start off by saying that I learned a lot from this course, and I do believe that Harvey cares very much about us as students. I appreciated his humor and little comics every lecture as well. However, his style of teaching was not conducive to my learning or engagement in the course. He spent every class reading his powerpoints almost entirely word-for-word, and it was difficult to stay engaged. I also feel that his expectations for us did not often align with what we thought was expected of us. The class as a whole did not do very well on the first exam, even though we'd all put a lot of hours into studying and preparing for it, and he told us that there is room for us to do better. I think that if he spent more time focusing on the important concepts that would be essential for assignments/exams in lecture, we'd all be on the same page.
Good instructor, seems to care a lot about students.  I really appreciated that the lectures were both in person and recorded online, as I could reference them when needed.
Very poor instruction. I have great respect for our instructor and he is definitely extremely knowledgable. I simply do not like his instruction.
Dr. Risch made himself very available to meet for any questions. However, again, he is just not great at lecturing. Lectures included reading off the slides with no additional explanation.

It is easy to tell that Harvey knows A TON about epidemiology. However, the way he communicates that information to students who have no background in the subject can be unclear at times. It would have been beneficial if he broke the material (and his slides) down more in a way for students to understand.

While he knew the material very well, he did not add anything to the lectures. He read off the slides, didn't add a personal anecdote or research project of his that would add to what we learned. His teaching style was overall robotic, and it wasn't engaging at all.

While I did not experience this first hand, I know others said he did not respond to constructive criticism well. Not engaging as a lecturer. Ppt slides were hard to interpret and poorly laid out. Not enough time spent on the harder concepts while more time spent on basics.

While I truly believe Professor Risch meant well, he was not a good fit to instruct this introductory course to first year MPH students. Many of us have never taken an epidemiology course before this one, but with his teaching styles and choice of language, you wouldn't know that. He often cited examples that students had no prior knowledge of. His strengths as a professor is that he is incredibly knowledgeable as  a professor of epidemiology and could answer any question. His weaknesses were his inability to engage with students, accurately answer their questions, test them in a meaningful way, and provide instruction and guidance in a way that students could learn from. Overall, I don't think he is a good fit for an instructor of this introductory course, but would be better fit to teach students who already have a firm grasp of the basics of epidemiology at a more advanced level.

Harvey Risch managed to be both condescending and incoherent in his lectures. While his slide shows were very detailed, his presentations would often turn into incomprehensible rambling about some topic that was not needed to understand the material. I often found that I understood the material worse after listening to him attempt to explain it. Most people in the class did not even attend the lectures, but I tried to give him a chance and went to most lectures. He would often take class time to criticize trends in the research community in a way that came off as condescending, especially since I am not primarily an epidemiology student (I have a different concentration). He also would give us rules about what language to use for epidemiology (for example calling people "patients" and not "cases" in a case-control study) that he would always forget to follow himself, so his criticisms of his colleagues seemed hypocritical and entirely out of place for an introductory class. During tests, he had a policy of not letting the TAs answer our questions for fear that different ones would answer the same question differently. Since many of the questions were due to his poor phrasing of exam questions, however, this policy was completely unjustifiable and made tests difficult for the wrong reasons. I feel I would have loved epidemiology if not for him.

Dr. Risch is very knowledgeable about the subject matter. That being said he is difficult to approach about any questions in the course.

STRENGTHS
-- The professor was responsive to student emails.
-- The professor has an endearing sense of humor and is demonstrably an expert in the field.
-- The professor apparently put a lot of thought into assembling the curriculum.
WEAKNESSES
-- There was minimal engagement with students during class. Reading off a PowerPoint that can be found verbatim on Canvas is redundant as a teaching tool. I recommend allowing 5-10 minutes during class for students to work through quantitative or qualitative questions in small groups, before reconvening to share conclusions with the larger group. I also recommend incorporating methods to gauge the classs understanding of the material during the lesson, and adjusting course accordingly (if 90% of students answer a question correctly, move on to a new subject; if 30% of students answer a question correctly, the educator has not effectively conveyed the concept and must backtrack, rephrase, explain, clarify, elicit questions from students).
I liked his dry sense of humor. The lectures could be more concise in my opinion.

Strengths: Very knowledgeable 
Weaknesses: Content could be delivered in a more effective way for an intro class since the material did not always seem to be presented in an effective way that was conducive to learning.

Dr. Risch is too smart to be teaching an introductory epidemiology course. He tried his best to make the content relatable, but sometimes he couldn't explain basic concepts because his practice is in more advanced epidemiology. This can be seen in his test questions, which presented more complicated than the content we learned. Overall, he was always there for questions or feedback.

He is obviously very knowledgeable and passionate about epidemiology, but for the first intro course for MPH students, his style was overwhelming. His slides were informative, but sometimes overly informative on his own philosophical asides, which were confusing during exams. He would be better suited for a second course, as I would see him being very engaging and interesting to discuss some of the details of epidemiology with. But learning these main concepts for the first time as well as parsing out what was common practice versus his own practice was confusing to say the least.

Harvey clearly enjoyed epidemiology and wanted to present the material to class in a clear and comprehensive way. Lectures were informative, but dry. I think the best way to improve the lectures would be to incorporate 2 or 3 practice problems into each lecture. In other words, after 20 or so minutes of lecturing, have a practice problem and give people 5 minutes to work on the problem in the middle of lecture. This would help people engage with the lecture material, give them a sense of how well they are understanding the material, and would vary the pacing of lectures. 

As stated in the previous response box, I think the most important change this class should make is how problem sets are graded -- they should be longer, worth 40 percent, and due BEFORE section starts.

Strength: The instructor knows the material very well.
Weakness: His lectures are not as clear as they could be.

Dr. Risch is insightful and critical on epi. He has his own view on some terms and topics. It great to learn those from him. He replies emails in his earliest convenience, which is what most instructors could not achieve. His cartoon images made epi class more fun. One suggestion I have for him is that - when preparing for class slides, is it possible to use different font/size to emphasize important concepts/points?

Dr. Risch is clearly passionate about epidemiology and hopes to inspire this passion in his students. However, I thought he could have made better use of the class time since the lectures were often much shorter than the time allotted. I was also concerned that hyper-critically evaluating the work of current faculty members in YSPH may have alienated some students.

I think a lot of the criticism Dr. Risch may receive in these evaluations stems from the fact that this was his first year teaching Epi I. Teaching a subject in which you are an expert at the introductory level is difficult, and I enjoyed learning from a professor who is so obviously eager to engage the next generation of epidemiologists.
the instructor is knowledgeable
Not the most engaging lecturer but very knowledgable
weaknesses: His lecture is too boring to participate and pay attention to him. He does not give much else information about his topic. He keeps reading his slide word by word.
Professor Risch is passionate about epidemiology and engaged in helping his students succeed.

Strengths - Professor Risch was an expertise in the field, and I like his dry humor and jokes he would insert into his lecture slides.
Weaknesses - He could have done a better job of explaining concepts in a more detailed way and given us more examples on how to perform calculations.  His exam questions were also sometimes poorly worded and made studying for exams extremely difficult.
Harvey is a very intelligent man, but not a great lecturer.  He does not captivate the audience and reads off of his slides, and for that reason most did not attend lecture.

Dr. Risch clearly knows a lot about epidemiology.  He often emphasized his epidemiologic expertise by providing criticism about studies done by other professionals, which was sometimes helpful to see others' errors and how to fix them, but other times this was off-putting and distracted from the lecture.  Dr. Risch also read directly from his powerpoint slides, which were full to the brim with text, leading to a disengaged student audience.

Overall, I still learned a lot from Dr. Risch as he was thorough and highlighted a lot of key aspirations and pitfalls of epidemiology.  I would suggest attempting to make lectures more engaging and manually calculating equations (when applicable) so that we can see the process, rather than looking at the already completed calculations on the powerpoint slides.

The instructor did very little in terms of actual teaching during the course based on the lectures. The powerpoints were sometimes very confusing, difficult to follow, and needed to be supplemented with outside sources for basic concepts. Additionally, lectures were not helpful to grasp of the material because they simply entailed a reading of the powerpoint. If the lecture was more comprehensive and extended past the powerpoint, it would have been more worthwhile to attend and pay attention to.
He may not be the most interesting and charismatic speaker, but he tries to engage his students and his powerpoint slides are very helpful!
Dr. Risch is a very intelligent person, that is clear, however, his method of teaching is quite dry and ineffective.

Dr. Risch is clearly a seasoned epidemiologist and knows how to frame epidemiologic concepts in very specific manner to help students avoid making mistakes in their usage of epi terms and frameworks.  It would be helpful if Dr. Risch brought in outside information from his own work and experiences to help students understand concepts more deeply and not read directly off class slides.
Excellent
Very knowledgeable.
I relied heavily on the textbook for explanations of difficult concepts.

This class gives a great foundation for epidemiological research, so I would absolutely recommend the class for anyone interested in pursuing public health. I came out of it feeling prepared to head into Epi II next semester.

The video lectures were the most positive aspect of this course. It is unfortunate that this class was taught in such a boring and monotone manner, especially at a place like Yale--YSPH, please do better when selecting professors for courses that students are required to take. With the time commitment that the homework assignments required, this portion of the course should have been raised to at least 30%. The exams were exercises in absolute subjectivity and frustration, with many fellow first-years agreeing that some of the questions in no way tested actual understanding of the material but rather obscure or random interpretations. Hoping that the mediocrity of required courses does not continue....

This course is not difficult, but Prof. Risch is a terrible professor who manages to be both condescending and incoherent in his lectures. He would always ramble on unrelated topics during lecture in a way that hampered proper understanding of the material and took the time to criticize his colleagues in a way that is out of place for an introductory lecture course. The weekly homework may have been a bit excessive, but if not for that and the TA sections explaining the answers, I would not have understood the material. This class would be a great introduction to epidemiology that gives you a new way of thinking about how to conduct and evaluated experiments, but his teaching made the experience less enjoyable.

This epidemiology course does give a great overview of all epidemiological concepts such as study design, screenings, bias, absolute and relative measures of association, and causation.
